Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 07:15AM - edited Jul 25, 2012 07:16AM by Christean Oh Abby, I know all too well what your feeling.  It is the scariest thing ever.  Be strong.  Don't panic.  Focus on one step at a time.  If you look at the big picture, it is just too overwhelming.  Just worry about today.  Tackle one decision at a time.  Most likely your next decision will be surgery.  Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy....bilateral vs. unilateral....reconstruction vs. no reconstruction...  Tissue Expanders vs. Flap....Port vs. no port, etc.  My advice to you is BE INFORMED.  Get educated about your options.  See a PS.  Look at pics.  Google Vinnie Myers and Renee Maschinot.  They are 3-D tattoist and have some great photos of reconstruction.  It will give you some realistic ideas of what your final reconstruction results would be.  There isn't one right answer for everyone.  It really is a personal choice.  You will know what is right for you. Be prepared for chemo.  At your age and HER2+ you will almost be guaranteed a spot in the chemo chair.  It's hard but it just means you have more big guns to fight with.  Take a big breath and buckle in for a long ride.  It's been almost 16 months since my diagnosis and I just finished with herceptin last week.  Don't stress about that too much though...One step at a time. If you have any questions about breast surgery/reconstruction, please PM me.  I will help any way I can. Congratulations on your baby.  Don't forget to enjoy him and love him.  Give that baby an extra tight hug tonight before bed.  Breast cancer can't take away the special experience of being a mom.  Keep living.  Best wishes. Christean
Posts.Title: I am so scared Abby20 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 08:07AM Christean wrote: Just one more thing...i would ask your onc. about a shingles vaccine before you start chemo.   I know it isn't FDA approved until your 50, but I would ask about it.  If I could do anything over again, it would be to get this vaccine if I could find a Dr. to administer it ...even if I had to pay for it out of pocket.  I got shingles last February.  It was the most miserable and painful thing ever.  If you could get the vaccine before the chemo drains your immune system it would be something to think about.
Posts.Title: I am so scared Abby20 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 09:46PM - edited Sep 7, 2011 09:51PM by Christean cgmartn12 - So sorry this has happened to you.  It is a scary time.  We have all been there.  This is a fabulous place for advice & support. Be strong.  You CAN do this.  I think half the battle is a positive attitude and a cheery outlook. Before you make your decision, I would get a consult with a plastic surgeon.  If you are even considering reconstruction you will need to evaluate your options before you even make a decision lumpectomy vs. mastectomy. As a PS nurse and a BC survivor who has also had to make these decisions for myself, I can tell you that radiation is a big factor when it comes to reconstruction.  You will probably not know before surgery if you will need radiation or not.  The need for radiation is usually dependant on 3 things:  1)  final tumor size 2) clear margins and 3) lymph node status.  All of these are unknown until your final pathology comes back.   If you do need radiation, you will need to do some research in order to make a knowlegeable decision.  Do not make a decision based on emotions or fear. Your options for reconstruction are typically either with a expander/implant or with a flap procedure.  Both types have pros and cons.  But, if you have radiation prior to reconstruction- you will most likely not have the option of expander/implant due to high risk of complications.  Your only option would be a flap procedure. If you do chose a mastectomy, one option is an immediate reconstruction with tissue expander placement which is done during the same surgery as your mastectomy.  Your PS and BS will work together.  It eliminates one surgery if you go this route, but you have to decide before you have the mastectomy. I have alot of experience with reconstruction and will try to offer any advice or answer any questions you have that might be helpful. Finally, remember this is a decision only you can make.  It is a very personal decision and there isn't one right or wrong answer.  Make the right answer for you and trust yourself and your doctors...and then get the ball rolling towards being a breast cancer survivor and moving forward.  It really helps to have a plan in place for surgery, MO visits, beginning of chemo etc.  Don't let anyone pressure you into one surgery vs. the other.  It has been my experience that BS and even MO steer towards lumpectomy.  But, remember...ultimately the choice is yours...and whatever path you choose will be the right one for you. Let me know if I can help you in any way.
Posts.Title: Surgery Questions cgmartn12 Pegs

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 09:58PM - edited Sep 7, 2011 09:59PM by Christean Sorry...just one more thought.  Please make sure you talk about a plan in the situation that you have surgery and your surgeon leaves on vacation the next day.  What happens if you have complications?  What doctor will be covering for her?  Will you stay overnight at the hosp?  What doctor is going to do rounds and discharge you?  How long will she be gone and when will your first post-op appt. be after your surgery? Make sure you know the plan and that you are comfortable and feel safe with it.
Posts.Title: Surgery Questions cgmartn12 Pegs

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2011 03:26PM Christean wrote: Periods just suck.  I am 39 and had TCH #3 on thursday.  My MO said my periods would stop but they haven't.  Very heavy flow...almost on time every month.  I made an appt. to see my GYN after having very low HGB.  He did a uterine biopsy and ultrasound of ovaries/uterus.  I'm still waiting on results for uterine biopsy,  but the US tech did tell me that I did have a uterine fibroid, which could be the reason for such heavy bleeding.  I think I will be looking at  either ablation, lupron injection or hysterectomy once chemo is done.  You are young, so it is not abnormal for your periods to return  post chemo.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Monthly Periods moe0279 LeapFrog39

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2011 02:09AM Christean wrote: Drains are lousy- so sorry all of you are having problems.  Does your surgeon have you wearing compression?  This will help keep the fluid away.  Ace bandages usually. The alterative to putting the drain back in is opening the incision to allow for the fluid to come out.  This involoves packing the area with gauze and then allowing it to heal from the inside out.  It's a long process and really sucks.  I'd pick having the drain put back in if I had a choice.
Posts.Title: anyone have return of the drains! dreidteacher kmpod

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 08:24PM Christean wrote: I have been an avid  user of Latisse for the last 2 years.  I have just doneTCH #2.  My hair begain falling out around day #14, and I buzzed it on day #21.  My lashes and brows are hanging on tight with the help of Latisse.  Everyone says they will fall out as well, but I am going to continue using the latisse and hoping.  My lashes are very long and everyone notices them now that I am bald.   If they do fall out, I am almost certain they will grow in faster if I use latisse.  I've had very good luck so far with it.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 11:32PM Christean wrote: Misswim, your story sounds very familiar... My lowest HGB was 8.4.  I felt like garbage when it was that low.  I did not want a transfusion.  I started taking Iron twice a day and my HGB slowly started to crawl back up.  My last HGB was 10.2.    If you take iron, make sure you take a stool softener.  Iron can cause wicked big C.
